conclusion: Analyze the path of light rays entering the semicircular glass brick and determine the exit region on the base.
Light rays strike the flat base of the semicircular glass brick at an angle \(\pi - \gamma\) relative to the horizontal.
The angle of incidence at the flat base is \(\gamma\).
Focus on the direct path of light as internal reflections are ignored.
The angle of refraction inside the glass is less than \(\gamma\).
The exact value of \(\theta\) is not needed for this problem.
Light travels in a straight line inside the glass until it reaches the semicircular surface.
At the semicircular surface, light can pass through or undergo total internal reflection.
If the angle of incidence at the semicircular surface is greater than \(\gamma\), total internal reflection occurs.
Light that passes through the semicircular surface exits at the flat base.
The exit region on the flat base is determined by the semicircle's geometry.
Light tangent to the semicircular surface forms a right triangle with the semicircle's radius.
The width of the exit region is twice the distance from the semicircle's center to the tangent ray's exit point.
This distance is \(R \cos \gamma\), making the width \(2R \cos \gamma\).
The width of the portion of the base through which light passes is \(\boxed{2R \cos \gamma}\).
